text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with santa maria tri-tip the famous
california barbecue black is beautiful
with this recipe this is a grilled
barbecued a piece of tri-tip beef and it
starts with a dry rub so i'm going to
take some salt some black pepper freshly
ground of course some paprika and i use
smoked paprika you can use regular sweet
paprika some garlic powder some onion
powder and some cayenne we're also going
to put in some dried rosemary and we're
going to mix that up so that's the dry
rub now the cut of meat we're using here
is called a tri-tip roast it's from the
bottom sirloin of beef and very common
in California you might have to ask your
butcher to cut you one if you live
somewhere else but I think these are
getting very popular around the country
so hopefully you can find a tri-tip
roast there usually are about two two
and a half pounds which is a perfect
size we're going to coat it very
generously on both sides with our dry
rub okay and I like to kind of Pat it in
a little bit with the tongs after it's
all sprinkled on I like to pick it up
and kind of get the edges with some of
the dry rub that fell off all right so
we're going to wrap that up and put it
in the refrigerator for four hours in
the meantime we're going to make a
little bit of a basting sauce so I have
some garlic cloves a little bit of
vegetable oil you want an unflavored oil
for this red wine vinegar and a little
dab of mustard which is going to help
emulsify this sauce when I shake it so
give it a shake and that's it now this
version we're doing is not really
traditional traditionally the only thing
this recipe got was the dry rub we're
actually going to have a little kind of
basting sauce to go with it to help
create that really signature dark black
caramelized crust alright four hours
later our tri-tip is ready to come out
we're going to let it sit at room
temperature for a half hour to warm up
we're going to go outside and I have a
very very hot grill okay the key to this
recipe is a really really hot flame you
really want to caramelize this crust
just black well done because there's no
sugar
in the sauce or in the rub you're not
going to get that nasty burn flavor
you're going to get these signature
Santamaria barbecue effect okay so
here's the drill
normally when we grill we just put the
meat on leave it turn it once until it's
done not with the santamar√≠a tri-tip all
right every three or four minutes you're
going to flip it baste it with your oil
and vinegar sauce and keep doing that
and it's going to take between 25
minutes and a half-hour if you've got a
really hot flame for this to come
medium-rare
now very important notice I'm turning
and then basting turning and then
basting if you baste and then turn and
then all that oil just pours in the fire
it's going to affect the flavor and it
won't be as good and also people will be
like hey we're dry bros go alright no
eyebrows is not a good look unless
you're you know Whoopi Goldberg so be
careful with that so it's based after
turning all right about a half-hour
later I used a thermometer to check
there's no shame okay don't go commando
use a thermometer it was just almost
1:30 I pulled it off let it sit minimum
minimum 10 minutes now the nice thing
about a tri-tip is when you cut it the
tips of the tip are going to be
well-done medium well medium sorta and
as you cut towards the center it will
become beautifully medium medium-rare
and if you're lucky there might even be
a rare slice or two in there so there's
something for everybody this is a great
cut of beef and the history is kind of
interesting this was actually a
specialty of the ranch hands
the Spanish ranchers back in the day
this was considered kind of a tough cut
of meat so they were given this piece
which they gladly accepted and grilled
over really hot red oak coals of course
they didn't tell the you know bosses how
delicious and juicy was they pretended
it was tough so that's kind of the
history but history schmick story who
cares it's delicious
don't be afraid of the black crust it's
part of the flavor profile and I hope
you give this a try ask your butcher for
tri-tip all the ingredients are on the
site and as always enjoy it
Oh
